description.value:
A nursing intervention is the care and/or treatment carried out by a nurse based on an expert opinion and clinical knowledge. It is part of the nursing process; interventions are determined as a result of indexed healthcare problems (nursing diagnoses) and based on treatment goals. Following the NEN-EN-ISO 18104 norm, it is possible to structure nursing interventions (or actions) in a hierarchy, where one intervention can be part of another intervention.
In a home care situation some actions can also be performed by the patient or a caregiver after a relevant instruction

purpose.value: This Procedure resource represents the Dutch [zib ('Zorginformatiebouwsteen', i.e. Health and Care Information Model) NursingIntervention-v3.2(2020EN)](https://zibs.nl/wiki/NursingIntervention-v3.2(2020EN)).

comment.value:
The zib NursingIntervention defines the concepts to describe nursing interventions across several use cases:
* as a singular event that has been performed * as a singular event that is planned or requested * as a repeating series of events that is planned, requested, or has been (partially) performed
However, in its current version, the zib only recognizes that these use cases exist and doesn't provide definitions on how to apply its data model to these different use cases. Nor does it specify a relation between instances of performed interventions and (series of) planned interventions.
Since FHIR-resources are assumed to describe either an event or a request, the interpretation of the zib in the context of FHIR is not straightforward. In [ZIB-2431](https://nictiz.atlassian.net/issues/ZIB-2431), a proposal in the interpretation of the interpretation of the different zib concepts in these different contexts is made. As a result, two different profiles are defined for zib NursingIntervention:
* The current profile on Procedure (zib-NursingIntervention-event) to register singular nursing interventions that are performed (or are to be performed). * A profile on ServiceRequest ([zib-NursingIntervention-request](http://nictiz.nl/fhir/StructureDefinition/zib-NursingIntervention-request)) to register planned and requested singular nursing interventions, and to describe series of nursing interventions.
In the ZIB ticket mentioned above, it has been recognized that not all concepts from the zib are applicable for every use case. For this reason, the following zib concepts are not represented in the current event profile:
* Interval (NL-CM:14.2.3): this concept is not relevant for performed singular events * Frequency (NL-CM:14.2.4): this concept is not relevant for performed singular events * Instruction (NL-CM:14.2.18): this concept is not relevant for performed singular events

comment.value: Please note that the zib limits the number of zib TreatmentObjective references to 1. Since this extension can be used for Goal references outside the scope of zib TreatmentObjective, the use of this extension has been left unconstrained.

definition.value: The start date (and if possible start time) of the procedure.

comment.value:
Zib concept ProcedureStartDateTime (NL-CM:14.2.11) is mapped both onto the DateTime and the Period data types of the `.performed[x]` element, as it can be interpreted in two different ways for performed singular nursing interventions (see [ZIB-2431](https://nictiz.atlassian.net/issues/ZIB-2431)):
* If the nursing intervention was an instantaneous event, ProcedureStartDateTime should be interpreted as the date/time of the intervention. For these situations, the DateTime data type should be used. * If the nursing intervention was an event that has taken some time, the ProcedureStartDateTime should be interpreted as the date/time when the intervention started, and is accompanied by a ProcedureEndDateTime for the date/time when the intervention ended. For these situations, the Period data type should be used. Note that ProcedeEndDateTime may be absent in case the intervention is still going on.

comment.value:
Zib NursingIntervention defines a reference to zib MedicalDevice, which is modelled using a combination of the DeviceUseStatement and Device resources. In the context of zib NursingIntervention however, this reference is limited in scope to the materials used, which is just a subset of the entire zib MedicalDevice. In FHIR this aligns with the Device resource.
For this reason, the MedicalDevice concept in zib NursingIntervention is only implemented as a reference to the [zib-MedicalDevice.Product](http://nictiz.nl/fhir/StructureDefinition/zib-MedicalDevice.Product) profile on Device, referenced from the `Procedure.usedReference` element. This aligns with the intention of the zib.
See [ZIB-2691](https://nictiz.atlassian.net/browse/ZIB-2691) for details.
